net.jbasics.util

Class Convert

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.jbasics.util.Convert

  • public final class Convert
extends Object

    Use these utility methods to convert one data type to another

     Why have yet another way to convert data types, when Java, Apache Commons, and other tools exist?

  Consider the following line of code:

    final int iVar = Convert.toInt(someObject);

    1) It's simple. When you need to convert one data type to another, just write what you're thinking:
          "convert this value to an integer"

    2) Ease of reading. There's no doubt about what the above line of code is doing,
          so no one reading it will be left guessing.

    3) Checks for the possibility of losing information about the magnitude of a value,
          and throws an exception if that would happen. So your code won't accidentally convert
          the number 80,000 to a short with the value of 14,464.

    4) Provides reasonable results when trying to convert null values: 0 for numbers, false for
          booleans, and empty string for strings. We can rid the world of ugly code like this:
           if ((object != null) && (object.getValue() > 0)) ...

    Narrowing conversion handling:

    • A narrowing conversion that would lose magnitude information always results in a run-time exception.
    • A narrowing conversion that would keep magnitude but lose precision does not throw an exception.
    • https://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jls/se8/html/jls-5.html#jls-5.1.3

    Default null handling:

    • for booleans, nulls are converted to false
    • for numbers, nulls are converted to zero
    • for strings, nulls are converted to empty string

    Other null handling:

    • You can call methods that define a different default value when null input values are passed in.

    Bit numbering: (LSB 0) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bit_numbering

        bit #: 7 6 5 4 3 2 1 0
    value: 1 0 0 1 0 1 1 0

    Byte numbering: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Endianness

        byte #:  3  2  1  0
    value:  7d f2 09 a3
    Version:
    2019-12-31
    Author:
    Rob Stoecklein

      • toLong

        public static long toLong(Object inputValue)
        Convert given input to a long.

        Equivalent to Convert.toLong(inputValue, 0L) 

            Convert.toLong(null)    = 0   // null
    Convert.toLong("  ")    = 0   // blank string
    Convert.toLong("936")   = 936 // numeric string
    Convert.toLong((byte)7) = 7   // byte
    Convert.toLong(8.4)     = 8   // double (rounds down)
    Convert.toLong(8.6)     = 9   // double (rounds up)
    Convert.toLong(true)    = 1   // boolean true
    Convert.toLong(false)   = 0   // boolean false
    Convert.toLong("abc")                  = X   // bogus string throws NumberFormatException
    Convert.toLong((List)list)             = X   // invalid class throws NumberFormatException
    Convert.toLong(BigInteger GT Long.MAX) = X   // out-of-range value throws ArithmeticException
        Parameters:
        inputValue - value to convert
        Returns:
        inputValue converted to a long, or zero if input is null or blank string

      • toLong

        public static Long toLong(Object inputValue,
                          Long defaultValue)
        Convert given input to a Long.

        Equivalent to 

            Convert.toLong(inputValue, defaultValue, false)
        Parameters:
        inputValue - value to convert
        defaultValue - value to use if input is null or blank string
        Returns:
        inputValue converted to a Long

      • toLong

        public static Long toLong(Object inputValue,
                          Long defaultValue,
                          boolean throwExceptionIfInputIsNullOrBlank)
        Convert given input to a Long.
        Parameters:
        inputValue - value to convert
        defaultValue - value to use if input is null or blank string
        throwExceptionIfInputIsNullOrBlank - flag that indicates to throw exception if input is null or blank string
        Returns:
        inputValue converted to a Long, or defaultValue if input is null or blank string
        Throws:
        NumberFormatException - if throwExceptionIfInputIsNullOrBlank is true and inputValue is null or blank string OR if inputValue class type does not allow conversion to Long
        ArithmeticException - if magnitude of converted inputValue would not fit into a Long object

      • toStr

        public static String toStr(Object inputValue)
        Convert the given object to its string equivalent, defaulting to the empty string if input is null or empty list.

        Same as calling: 

            Convert.toStr(inputObject, "")
 
            Convert.toStr(null)                  = ""
    Convert.toStr("  ")                  = "  "
    Convert.toStr("abc")                 = "abc"
    Convert.toStr(357)                   = "357"
    Convert.toStr(24.68)                 = "24.68"
    Convert.toStr((char)35)              = "#"
    Convert.toStr([empty List])          = "[]"
    Convert.toStr([empty Map])           = "{}"
    Convert.toStr([empty StringBuilder]) = ""
    Convert.toStr([empty StringBuffer])  = ""
    Convert.toStr(new byte[]{0x46, 0x28, 0x70} = "F(p"
    Convert.toStr(new byte[]{0x46, 0x28, 0x70} = "F(p"
        Parameters:
        inputValue - -
        Returns:
        value converted to String

      • toStringArray

        public static String[] toStringArray(List<String> list)
        Converts a List of Strings to an array of Strings. 
            Convert.toStringArray(null)            = [];    // null input
    Convert.toStringArray([])              = [];    // empty list
    Convert.toStringArray(["a", "b", "c"]) = ["a", "b", "c"];   // list

      • toList

        @SafeVarargs
public static <T> List<T> toList(T... array)
        Converts an array of type "T" to a List of type "T". 
            Convert.toList(null)            = [];
    Convert.toList("")              = [];
    Convert.toList([1, 2, 3])       = [1, 2, 3];
    Convert.toList([1.1, 2.2, 3.3]) = [1.1, 2.2, 3.3];
    Convert.toList(["abc", "xyz"])  = ["abc", "xyz"];
        Parameters:
        array - (either Object... or Object[])

      • stringToPrimitiveDoubleArray

        public static double[] stringToPrimitiveDoubleArray(String input)
        Converts a string of comma-delimited numbers into an array of doubles.

      • stringToPrimitiveDoubleArray

        public static double[] stringToPrimitiveDoubleArray(String input,
                                                    String separator)
        Converts a string of separator-delimited numbers into an array of doubles. 
            Convert.stringToPrimitiveDoubleArray(null, "@")                  = []                      // null
    Convert.stringToPrimitiveDoubleArray("", "$")                    = []                      // empty string
    Convert.stringToPrimitiveDoubleArray("12.3#45.6#78.9", "#")      = [12.3, 45.6, 78.9]      // standard list
    Convert.stringToPrimitiveDoubleArray(" 1.4 ^ 2.5 ^ ^ 3.6 ", "^") = [1.4, 2.5, 0, 3.6]      // extra spaces and missing item

      • toCommaSeparatedString

        public static <T> String toCommaSeparatedString(Collection<T> items)
        Convert the given Collection of items Type into a comma-separated String.

      • toPercentage

        public static double toPercentage(double partial,
                                  double total)
        Convert the two values into a percentage. 
            Convert.toPercentage(0.0, 100.0)   = 0.0
    Convert.toPercentage(25.0, 100.0)  = 25.0
    Convert.toPercentage(133.0, 100.0) = 133.0
    Convert.toPercentage(1.234, 6.789) = 18.176462
    Convert.toPercentage(10.0, 0.0)    = Infinity

      • toStrFmt

        public static String toStrFmt(Object obj,
                              String format)
        Format the input data value using the given the format. 
            Convert.toStrFmt(null,  null)      = ""
    Convert.toStrFmt(4,     null)      = "4"
    Convert.toStrFmt(1.23,  null)      = "1.23"
    Convert.toStrFmt("hey", null)      = "hey"
    Convert.toStrFmt(17,    " 4d")     = "  17"
    Convert.toStrFmt(32,    "03d")     = "032"
    Convert.toStrFmt(122,   "04x")     = "007a"
    Convert.toStrFmt(1.23,  ".1f")     = "1.2"
    Convert.toStrFmt(78.9,  "e")       = "7.890000e+01"
    Convert.toStrFmt("hey", "s")       = "hey"
    Convert.toStrFmt(234,   "0X%1$2X") = "0XEA"      // includes "%1$" plus extra characters
    Convert.toStrFmt("hey", ".1f")     = ""          // bogus

      • nanosToMillis

        public static double nanosToMillis(double nanos)
        Convert nanoseconds to milliseconds. 
            Convert.nanosToMillis(0.0)         = 0.0
    Convert.nanosToMillis(4_123_567.8) = 4.1235678

      • millisToNanos

        public static double millisToNanos(double millis)
        Convert milliseconds to nanoseconds. 
            Convert.millisToNanos(0.0)      = 0.0
    Convert.millisToNanos(13.57982) = 13579820.0

      • millisToSeconds

        public static double millisToSeconds(double millis)
        Convert milliseconds to seconds. 
            Convert.millisToSeconds(0.0)     =  0.0
    Convert.millisToSeconds(12.34)   =  0.01234
    Convert.millisToSeconds(900.0)   =  0.9
    Convert.millisToSeconds(2000.0)  =  2.0
    Convert.millisToSeconds(-5678.9) = -5.6789

        Convert milliseconds to minutes.

    Convert.secondsToMillis(3.45678) =  3456.78
    Convert.secondsToMillis(-6.78)   = -6780.0

    Convert.secondsToMinutes(60)     =  1.0

    Convert.secondsToMinutes(3678.9) = 61.315
